publicwhip.spmotion: * S2M-2926 Bill Butler: Sense Over Sectarianism—That the Parliament welcomes the relaunch of the “Sense Over Sectarianism” scheme organised by Glasgow City Council in partnership with the Scottish Executive, Nil by Mouth, Rangers Football Club, Celtic Football Club, the Catholic Church and the Church of Scotland; commends this effort to highlight the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities throughout Scotland; recognises the importance of supporting community-based projects to tackle sectarianism and the use of educational resources within schools to show young people that such behaviour is completely unacceptable in 21st century Scotland, and welcomes all efforts by the Executive, local authorities, voluntary organisations, community groups, churches and sports clubs in tackling sectarian attitudes directly. Supported by: Robert Brown*, Alex Johnstone*, Sarah Boyack*, Murray Tosh*, Mr Alasdair Morrison*, Mrs Mary Mulligan*, Mr Kenny MacAskill*, Roseanna Cunningham*, Trish Godman*, Donald Gorrie*, Ms Sandra White*

S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) Mr John Swinney*, Helen Eadie*, Michael McMahon*, Cathie Craigie*, Tommy Sheridan*, Jackie Baillie*, Alex Fergusson*, Patrick Harvie*, Marlyn Glen*, Mike Watson*, Marilyn Livingstone*, Robin Harper*, Mr Frank McAveety*, Michael Matheson*, Rob Gibson*, Mrs Margaret Ewing*, Shiona Baird*, Janis Hughes*

S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) Maureen Macmillan*, Bristow Muldoon*, Mr Andrew Arbuckle*, John Home Robertson*, Ms Wendy Alexander*, Mr Stewart Maxwell*, Linda Fabiani*, Chris Ballance*, Elaine Smith*, Alex Neil*, Mark Ballard*

S2M-2926 Bill Butler: Sense Over Sectarianism—That the Parliament welcomes the relaunch of the “Sense Over Sectarianism” scheme organised by Glasgow City Council in partnership with the Scottish Executive, Nil by Mouth, Rangers Football Club, Celtic Football Club, the Catholic Church and the Church of Scotland; commends this effort to highlight the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities throughout Scotland; recognises the importance of supporting community-based projects to tackle sectarianism and the use of educational resources within schools to show young people that such behaviour is completely unacceptable in 21st century Scotland, and welcomes all efforts by the Executive, local authorities, voluntary organisations, community groups, churches and sports clubs in tackling sectarian attitudes directly. Supported by: Robert Brown, Alex Johnstone, Sarah Boyack, Murray Tosh, Mr Alasdair Morrison, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Mr Kenny MacAskill, Roseanna Cunningham, Trish Godman, Donald Gorrie, Ms Sandra White, Mr John Swinney, Helen Eadie, Michael McMahon, Cathie Craigie, Tommy Sheridan, Jackie Baillie, Alex Fergusson, Patrick Harvie, Marlyn Glen, Mike Watson, Marilyn Livingstone, Robin Harper, Mr Frank McAveety, Michael Matheson, Rob Gibson, Mrs Margaret Ewing, Shiona Baird, Janis Hughes, Maureen Macmillan, Bristow Muldoon, Mr Andrew Arbuckle, John Home Robertson, Ms Wendy Alexander, Mr Stewart Maxwell, Linda Fabiani, Chris Ballance, Elaine Smith, Alex Neil, Mark Ballard, Ms Rosemary Byrne*, Rosie Kane*
S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) Stewart Stevenson*
S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) Eleanor Scott*
S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) Dennis Canavan*, Dr Jean Turner*, Karen Gillon*, Nora Radcliffe*, Cathy Peattie*
S2M-2926 Sense Over Sectarianism (lodged on 7 June 2005) John Swinburne*
